metadata.title: Enhanced electron transfer and methane production from low-strength wastewater using a new granular activated carbon modified with nano-Fe3O4

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/cej
Enhanced electron transfer and methane production from low-strength wastewater using a new granular activated carbon modified with nanoFe3O4 Xiangru Song, Jia Liu⁎, Qing Jiang, Peng Zhang, Yuqiang Shao, Weihua He, Yujie Feng⁎
State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology. No 73 Huanghe Road, Nangang District, Harbin 150090, China
H I G H L I G H T S
• A novel conductive nanomaterial prepared by facile co-precipitation method. • Methane production was improved in the anaerobic system with conductive nanomaterial. • Conductive nanomaterial enhanced the electron transfer in the methanogenesis. • Electron capacity of the conductive nanomaterial was enhanced by loading of nano-Fe3O4.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Granular activated carbon Low-strength wastewater Nano-Fe3O4 Methanogenesis Electron transfer
A B S T R A C T
Granular activated carbon (GAC) was modified by the addition of conductive nano-Fe3O4 for use in the anaerobic digestion of low-strength wastewater. This new material, called magnetic granular activated carbon (MGAC), was fabricated by the facile co-precipitation method. The MGAC exhibited superior electro-conductivity, electron transfer rate, and methane production. The observed conductivity of the MGAC (17.5 ± 0.6mS cm−1) was 2.03 times that of the GAC (8.6 ± 0.3mS cm−1). With the MGAC, the effluent total chemical oxygen demand concentration (44.5 ± 1.5mg L−1) was 33% lower than that obtained with the GAC and 43% lower than that obtained in the control experiment (with no conductive additive). The methane production obtained with the MGAC (4.7 ± 0.2mL per cycle) was 3.6 times that of the control and 1.57 times that of the GAC. The anaerobic system with the MGAC exhibited stronger electrochemical response to riboflavin and cytochrome C. The peak current at 0 V (reduction peak, cytochrome C) of the MGAC was 45.1 μA, which was 54.0% higher than that of the GAC and 54.8% higher than that of the control. The electron accepting capability [56.71 ± 0.70 μmol e− (g char)−1] was 2.75 times that of the GAC. The MGAC also exhibited a higher abundance of functional microorganisms. These results demonstrated that the MGAC enhanced the electron transfer between bacteria and archaea, improved methane production, and produced high-quality effluent.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The use of anaerobic digestion for the treatment of domestic
wastewater has attracted worldwide attention because of its municipal advantages over traditional aerobic treatment. These advantages include the recovery of carbon resource and reductions in both energy
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2019.05.216 Received 27 March 2019; Received in revised form 21 May 2019; Accepted 29 May 2019
⁎ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: jia14921@163.com (J. Liu), yujief@hit.edu.cn (Y. Feng).
Chemical Engineering Journal 374 (2019) 1344–1352
Available online 30 May 2019 1385-8947/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
consumption and residual sludge. However, low-strength wastewater does not meet the organic concentration requirements for anaerobic digestion because of its low degradation rate and low electron transfer efficiency [1]. Therefore, it is necessary to accelerate electron transfer during anaerobic digestion of low-strength wastewater by adding conductive materials.
Recently, direct interspecies electron transfer (DIET) between Geobacter and Methanothrix species has been confirmed to occur during methane production [2]. Moreover, naturally occurring or artificially supplemented conductive materials can facilitate the DIET process by acting as a bridge connecting the cell surfaces of electron-donating and electron-accepting microbes [3]. These conductive materials, such as polyaniline (PANI), granular activated carbon (GAC) and magnetite, have been found to enhance the DIET process [4–6]. PANI acts as an electron aisle that accelerates electron transfer and improves methane production [5]. GAC is used in anaerobic digestion because it is inexpensive, in addition to having no biological toxicity, high surface area, and numerous pores that are available for modifications [7]. As a carrier of microorganisms, GAC is used in the anaerobic digestion of low-strength wastewater for enhancing electron transfer between exoelectrogens and methanogens [8,9]. Magnetite is a common ironbearing material that can improve interspecies electron transfer and enhance methane generation [3]. Ferrosoferric oxide (Fe3O4), which is the main component of magnetite, has been confirmed to improve methane production by enhancing electron transfer [10]. Extracellular solid conductive materials can transfer electrons between bacteria as pili or c-type cytochromes, and they can be used as electron donors or acceptors for the growth of these microorganisms [11]. Therefore, the use of conductive materials can promote methane production during the anaerobic digestion process.
Nano-Fe3O4 and Fe3O4 nano-composites possess strong electrical and magnetic properties, large specific surface area, small size distribution, low toxicity, and high biocompatibility [12–16]. Nano-Fe3O4 has received increasing consideration as a catalyst in anaerobic digestion due to its ease of handling, recovery with an external magnetic field, and high catalytic activity in various organic transformations [17]. In addition, nano-Fe3O4 can strengthen the electron transfer process and is capable of inducing dissimilatory iron reduction, which facilitates energy recovery from wastewater [18–20]. However, nanoFe3O4 particles often tend to aggregate due to nanometer-scale and magnetic effects during catalytic transformations, which remarkably decreases catalytic activity owing to the decrease in active surface area [12]. Thus, to increase the availability of catalytic sites, it is necessary to load the nano-Fe3O4 particles onto a porous and biocompatible carrier that avoids agglomeration of the nanoparticles and disperses them to the pores and surface of the carrier. Loading nano-Fe3O4 onto porous GAC can improve the conductivity of GAC and provide more electron transfer sites, which in turn increases the electron transfer rate between the microorganisms.
To enhance energy recovery from low-strength wastewater using anaerobic digestion technology, this study investigates a new GAC material modified with nano-Fe3O4. This material, called magnetic granular activated carbon (MGAC), is developed in the present study and fabricated by the co-precipitation method. This study also investigates the effects of MGAC on methane production and removal of total chemical oxygen demand (tCOD) from low-strength wastewater, as well as the electron transfer mechanism between the microorganisms.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
GAC (10–30 mesh) was provided by Shenyang Chemical Co., and ferrous chloride (anhydrous, 99.8%) and ferric chloride (anhydrous, 99.8%) were obtained from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd
(Tianjin, China). Ammonium hydroxide (AR, 25%, Tianjin Zhiyuan Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, Tianjin, China) was used as the precipitant. Deionized (DI) water (Milli-Q system, USA) was also used in the experiment.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of magnetic activated carbon
sections.text: FeCl2·4H2O (1.9043 g), FeCl3·6H2O (4.6602 g), and GAC (2 g) were added to 40mL of DI water, and the mixture was stirred for 30min at ambient temperature. Next, ammonium hydroxide (20mL) and 20mL of DI water were added to the abovementioned mixture and continuously stirred for 30min. Then, the mixture was filtered with a 60- mesh strainer to remove the suspended nano-Fe3O4. The MGAC complexes obtained were separated from the mixture by a magnet, rinsed with DI water five times, and dried completely in a vacuum oven (DZF6030A, Shanghai Yiheng Scientific instrument Co., Ltd, Shanghai, China) at 40 °C for more than 24 h.

sections.heading: 2.3. Construction and operation of anaerobic system
sections.text:
A batch anaerobic system was constructed with 100mL serum bottles (Fig. S1) that each contained 30mL of anaerobic sludge and 40mL of substrate. Nitrogen gas was applied for 10min to remove air from the bottles. The bottles were sealed with rubber stoppers and placed in a constant-temperature oscillation incubator (HZQ-C, Harbin Dongming Medical Instrument, Harbin, China) at 105 rpm and 35 °C.
The anaerobic reactors were operated for 50 days a cycle time of 48 h. The substrate (40mL) was replaced with fresh substrate (40mL) after each cycle. After obtaining stable methane production and chemical oxygen demand (COD) removal rate, 6 g of the GAC and MGAC were added in different anaerobic bottles. The anaerobic bottles that were not treated with GAC or MGAC were denoted as controls. The concentrations of tCOD and methane were analyzed periodically, and the methane production was collected by a gas bag. Each reactor was prepared in triplicate. The anaerobic sludge (VSS/TSS 0.79 ± 0.003) was obtained from a laboratory anaerobic reactor that was operated replacing this selection with simulated domestic wastewater (400mg L−1 COD) over two months [21]. The substrate contained the following compounds [22–24]: sodium acetate (0.51 g L−1, COD 400mg L−1), NH4Cl (0.4 g L−1), NaHCO3 (1 g L−1), MgSO4·7H2O (0.4 g L−1), KCl (0.4 g L−1), CaCl2·2H2O (0.5 g L−1), (NH4)2HPO4 (0.08 g L−1), FeCl3·6H2O (0.005 g L−1), KI (0.01 g L−1), MnCl2·4H2O (0.0005 g L−1), CuCl2·2H2O (0.0005 g L−1), ZnCl2 (0.0005 g L−1), AlCl3·6H2O (0.0005 g L−1), NaMoO4·2H2O (0.0005 g L−1), Na2SeO3 (0.0005 g L−1), H3BO3 (0.0005 g L−1), CoCl2·6H2O (0.001 g L−1).

sections.heading: 2.4. Analysis and calculation
sections.text:
The MGAC morphology was observed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi Ltd. S-4700), and the nano-Fe3O4 electron diffraction pattern was observed using a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEM2100F, JEOL). The element content was analyzed using an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). Prior to examination with the HRTEM, the MGAC was ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol for 30min, dropped onto a double-sided copper network, and dried under ambient conditions. Hydrophilicity was characterized by contact angle using a surface contact angle measurement instrument (JYSP-360, USA; needlepoint size= 1.5 mm). The MGAC conductivity was investigated using a double testing digital four-probe tester (ST2263, Suzhou Jingge Electronic Co., Ltd, China).
A Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, Spectrum One B, Perkin Elmer Inc.) was used to record spectra on the range of 4000–400 cm−1. The crystallographic structures of the nano-Fe3O4 materials were observed using X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 Advance, Bruker Daltonics Inc., Germany), with Cu Kα radiation and 2θ values in the range of 10–70°. The specific surface area of the particles was
examined using BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) (ASAP 2020 V 3.00 H). The tCOD was obtained directly from the liquid supernatant and measured using standard methods (HACH DR/3900 Spectrophotometer, HACH Co., Loveland, Co., USA). The adsorption performance of the particles for the simulated wastewater (tCOD=400mg L−1) was investigated. The control was the pure substrate without conductive particles. The mass of particles added (6 g) was the same as that of the anaerobic system. The biogas products were analyzed by GC using Agilent 7872 series with the FID detector. The riboflavin content was investigated by UPLC (Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography).

sections.heading: 2.5. Electrochemical analysis
sections.text:
Electrochemical tests were conducted at ambient temperatures using an electrochemical workstation (Chenhua CH760E, China) with a three-electrode setup. A graphite plate (1×2 cm2) was used as the working electrode, while a Pt sheet and saturated calomel electrode (+242mV vs. Standard hydrogen electrode, SHE, Spsic-Rex Instrument Factory, China) were used as the counter electrode and the reference electrode, respectively.
To investigate the electrochemical activity and extracellular electron transfer of the MGAC, cyclic voltammetry (CV) and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) were performed using the three electrodes [25]. The CV and DPV tests were conducted after the substrate had been consumed completely. The working electrode was inserted into the sludge and placed in full contact with the MGAC. For the CV tests, the working electrode potential was scanned from +1 to −1 V at a scan rate of 10–200mV s−1. The DPV tests were performed by scanning from +1 to −1 V at a scan rate of 1mV s−1 with amplitude of 50mV, pulse width of 0.3 s, pulse period of 1 s and quiet time of 2 s [26].
The MGAC electron-accepting and electron donating capacities (EAC and EDC, respectively) were evaluated using amperometric i-t curve. These curves were obtained from tests performed using the three electrodes in a phosphate buffer solution (0.1M, pH 7.0) with KCl (0.1 M) as the electrolyte [27]. The mediated electrochemical reduction (MER) was analyzed using an electron shuttle zwitterionic viologen 4,4′-bipyridinium-1,1′-bis(2-ethylsulfonate) (DQ, Sigma-Aldrich) at an applied potential of −0.49 V (vs. SHE). The mediated electrochemical
oxidation (MEO) was analyzed using an electron shuttle 2,2′-azino-bis (3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) diammonium salt, (ABTS,> 98%, Sigma -Aldrich) at an applied potential of +0.61 V (vs. SHE). The phosphate buffer with KCl (72mL) and electron shuttle (0.1 mL) were added to the cells. The solution was aerated by nitrogen for 30min to remove oxygen from the system before the test. After attaining a constant background, the solution prepared by the particles (2 mL of 3 g L–1) was added to the cells twice. The electron exchange capacity [EEC, mmol e–1 (g char)–1] was calculated as EEC= EAC+ EDC, where
∫= = ∫ EAC EDC I m dt m, / /m ox char char Ired mchar dt char , Ired is the baseline-corrected reductive current (A) in the MER, Iox is the baseline-corrected oxidative (A), F is the Faraday constant (96485 s Amole−–1), and t is the duration time of the current peak (s).

sections.heading: 2.6. Analysis of microbial community composition
sections.text: The microbial community composition was analyzed by pyrosequencing, which was conducted by Sangon Biotech Company using a Roche 454 GS-FLX instrument. The bacterial 16S rDNA PCR (polymerase chain reaction) was performed using 341F (CCTACGGGNGGCWGCAG) and 805R (GACTACHVGGGTATCTAATCC) primers targeting the variable region V3–V4. The archaeal 16S rDNA Nested PCR was performed using two pairs of PCR primers, 304F (CCCTAYGGGGYGCASCAG) - 1000R (GGCCATGCACYWCYTCTC) and 349F (GYGCASCAGKCGMGAAW) - 806R (GGACTACVSGGGTATCTAAT) targeting the variable region V3–V4 [28]. The functional differences between the different samples were analyzed by functional genes speculated from the results of the 16S sequencing [29].

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of MGAC
sections.text:
The GAC particles had protrusion and fissures, and they adhered to activated carbon fragments of smaller sizes (Fig. 1A). The needleshaped and spherical nanoparticles were irregularly loaded on the MGAC. The nanoparticles were also scattered on the surfaces and in the pores of the MGAC (Fig. 1B). A distinct reduction in pore width was
observed on the surfaces of the MGAC particles due to the introduction of the nanoparticles. Meanwhile, SEM-EDS images of the MGAC confirmed the atom dispersion of iron oxide (Fig. S2). The HRTEM images of the MGAC provided further evidence of the size of the nano-Fe3O4 particles (Fig. 1C). Deep black nanoparticles with an average diameter of 10 nm were formed. The interplanar distance, as calculated from this figure, was about 0.45 nm, which is consistent with the lattice plane of nano-Fe3O4 [30].
The broadbands of the particles, with relatively low intensity centered at 1572 cm−1 and 1559 cm−1 can be attributed to the bending vibrations of adsorbed water (Fig. 2A). The FTIR spectrum of the MGAC exhibited broadband at 560 cm−1, which corresponds to Fe-O stretching vibration [31]. The XRD images showed that Fe3O4 was formed in the MGAC (Fig. 2B). The apparent peaks at 25° correspond to the sheet structure of C (0 0 6) in all the patterns. The diffraction peaks at the 2θ values of 30.2°, 35.5°, 43.3°, 57.6°, and 62.9° were associated with the (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (4 0 0), (5 1 1), and (4 4 0) planes of the cubic spinel structure of Fe3O4, respectively [32]. The FTIR and XRD results further confirmed that the nanoparticles in the MGAC were composed of Fe3O4.
The hydrophilicity and conductivity of the MGAC were enhanced by nano-Fe3O4. The contact angle of MGAC was 95 ± 0.9°, which was 22.7% lower than that of GAC (123 ± 0.4°) (Fig. S3). The enhanced hydrophilicity led to a higher affinity between the particles and the substrate, which decreased the mass transfer resistance [33]. The conductivity of the particles increased after loading nano-Fe3O4 (Fig. S4). The MGAC (17.5 ± 0.6mS cm−1) produced higher conductivity, which was 2.03 times of the GAC (8.6 ± 0.3mS cm−1). The higher
conductivity of MGAC improved the electron transfer between the bacteria and the archaea, which can increase the digestion rate of the substrate [18].
The BET results showed that the surface area (SBET) of the MGAC was 688m2 g−1, which was 93% higher than that of the GAC (356m2 g−1). The majority of the pores of the particles were in the mesoporous range (Fig. S5). The internal average diameter of the MGAC particles was in the range of 2.1–37.6 nm, which indicates that the MGAC was predominantly mesoporous. The internal average diameter of the GAC was in the range of 2.1–249.9 nm, and 99.8% of the GAC pores were in the mesoporous range. The maximum pore size of the MGAC (0–5 nm) included 96.3% of its distribution, which was 20% higher than that of the GAC (80.1%). The MGAC had smaller pores, which implied a higher surface area. The nano-Fe3O4 particles deposited in the channels of the GAC were significantly smaller than the GAC pores. Since these particles were not large enough to block the GAC pores, the specific surface area of the resulting MGAC increased.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of particles on tCOD removal and methane production
sections.text:
The tCOD removal rate was increased by the addition of the nanoparticles (Fig. 3). The highest tCOD removal rate obtained with the MGAC was 88.9 ± 0.4%, which was 10% higher than that of the control (80.5 ± 0.5%). The lowest effluent tCOD obtained with the MGAC was 44.5 ± 1.5mg L–1, which was 43% lower than that of the control (78.0 ± 2.0mg L–1), and 33% lower than that of the GAC (66.5 ± 1.5mg L–1). This result indicates that the MGAC enhanced the effluent quality. The adsorption performance of the particles (with no microorganisms) for tCOD (in pure simulated wastewater) was investigated (Fig. S6). Within the test period (6.5 h), the MGAC produced a residual tCOD concentration of 133 ± 1mg L–1, which was 17% lower than that of the GAC (160 ± 1mg L–1). The MGAC exhibited higher adsorption capacity for tCOD (1.6 ± 0.1mg tCOD g−1), which
was 23.1% higher than that of the GAC (1.3 ± 0.1mg tCOD g−1). The MGAC exhibited faster adsorption and higher adsorption capacity for tCOD than those of the GAC. This result indicates that the MGAC provided more substrates for the microorganisms per unit time, which in turn accelerated the degradation rate and improved the tCOD removal. The MGAC had a higher specific surface area, which indicates a higher adsorption capacity for substrate and a higher degradation rate [34].
The MGAC generated 4.7 ± 0.2mL (0.32 ± 0.01 L CH4 g tCODremoved–1) of methane over one cycle, which was 3.6 times that of the control (1.3 ± 0.1mL, 0.10 ± 0.01 L CH4 g tCODremoved–1) and also 57% higher than that of the GAC (3.0 ± 0.4mL, 0.22 ± 0.01 L CH4 g tCODremoved–1) (Fig. 4A). The proportion of methane in the biogas was increased by the addition of the conductive particles (Fig. 4B). The highest proportion of methane obtained with the MGAC was 69.8 ± 0.2%, which was 25% higher than that of the control (55.7 ± 0.6%) and 10% higher than that of the GAC (63.2 ± 0.1%).
The MGAC increased tCOD removal efficiency and methane production because the nano-Fe3O4 had a bio-stimulating effect on the methanogens, which in turn facilitated the conversion of the substrate to methane [35]. In addition, the conductivity of the MGAC increased, and thus bridged the cell connection and accelerated the electron transfer [18]. These results indicate that the application of MGAC in the anaerobic digestion of low-strength wastewater can enhance methane generation and improve effluent quality.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of particles on redox properties
sections.text:
The CV tests (without substrates) were used to investigate the electrochemical behavior of the MGAC. A pair of symmetric peaks at −0.3 V (vs. SCE, oxidation peak) and −0.5 V (vs. SCE, reduction peak) was observed in the CV curves at different scan rates (Fig. 5). The electrochemical response was increased by the addition of the conductive particles. The highest peak currents for the MGAC (at the scan rate of 200mV s−1) were 1.26mA and 1.44mA at −0.3 V and −0.5 V, respectively. These values were 29.9% and 17.1% higher than those of
the control (0.97mA and 1.23mA, respectively). The peak currents of the GAC (1.15 mA and 1.40mA, respectively) were slightly lower than those of the MGAC.
The effect of the scan rate on the peak current indicates the controlled step in the electron transfer process [36–39]. When the scan rate was increased from 10 to 200mV s−1, the potentials shifted negatively and the current peak intensity increased. The logarithm of the peak currents at −0.3 V and −0.5 V were proportional to the logarithm of the scan rate, and the slopes were between 0.5 and 1, which indicates that the adsorption and diffusion processes controlled the electrochemical reaction (Fig. 5B, D, and F). When the scan rate was increased from 10 to 100mV s−1, the slopes of all the test systems were between 0.5 and 1, which indicates that the adsorption and diffusion processes controlled the electrochemical reaction at the same time (Fig. S7A, C, and E). When the scan rate was increased from 100 to 200mV s−1, the slopes of the control system decreased and approached 0.5, which indicates that the diffusion process controlled the electrochemical reaction (Fig. S7B). The slopes of the GAC and MGAC increased and approached 1.0, which indicated that the surface adsorption was stronger than diffusion (Fig. S7D and F). The electrons were transferred to the working electrode by the conductive particles, and these electrons reacted directly on the electrode surface. These results indicate that the conductive particles acted as a bridge to enhance the electron transfer.
DPV tests with higher sensitivity were performed to detect the electrochemically active substance and further elucidate the electron transfer pathway [40]. A pair of symmetric peaks began to appear with the oxidation peak at −0.3 V (vs. SCE) and the reduction peak at −0.4 V (vs. SCE) (Fig. 6), which matched the characteristic peak of riboflavin [41]. The peak current was increased by the addition of the particles. The peak current at −0.3 V (oxidation peak) of the MGAC was 83.8 μA, which was 43.3% higher than that of the control (58.4 μA) and 11.6% higher than that of the GAC (75.1 μA). The peak current at −0.4 V (reduction peak) of the MGAC was 81.8 μA, which was 42.0% higher than that of the control (57.6 μA) and 15.9% higher than that of the GAC (70.6 μA). The concentration of riboflavin was increased by the addition of the conductive particles (Fig. S8). The highest concentration of riboflavin for the MGAC (1.31 ± 0.06mg L–1) was 31.0% higher than that of the control (1.00 ± 0.01mg L–1) and 16.7% higher than that of the GAC (1.12 ± 0.02mg L–1). These results indicate that both the GAC and the MGAC can enhance the indirect electron transfer (IET) by riboflavin.
A reduction peak appeared at 0 V (vs. SCE), which matches the characteristic peak of cytochrome C [42]. The peak current at 0 V (reduction peak) of the MGAC was 45.1 μA, which was 54.8% higher than that of the control (29.1 μA) and 54.0% higher than that of the GAC (29.3 μA). The conductivity of the MGAC was increased by the addition of nano-Fe3O4. As a conductive conduit, this addition accelerated the process by which the cytochrome C transmitted electrons to the extracellular electron receptors and thus enhanced the DIET [43]. An oxidation peak appeared at 0.75 V (vs. SCE), which matches the characteristic peak of guanine [44]. The Fe (III) in the substrate oxidized the guanine in the DNA during the DPV test, which in turn increased the electrochemical response. Because the MGAC was loaded with nanoFe3O4, this addition enhanced the response of the guanine.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of particles on electron transmission
sections.text:
The MGAC and GAC exhibited well-defined, baseline-separated reductive and oxidative current responses in the MER and MEO (Fig. 7). The EDC of the MGAC [2.23 ± 0.03 μmol e– (g char)–1] and the GAC [2.29 ± 0.02 μmol e– (g char)–1] were similar, which indicates that the carbon component donated electrons to the cell. The EAC of the MGAC [56.71 ± 0.70 μmol e– (g char)–1] was 1.75 times higher than that of the GAC [20.61 ± 0.22 μmol e– (g char)–1]. The EEC of the MGAC [58.94 ± 0.67 μmol e– (g char)–1] was 1.57 times higher than that of the GAC [22.90 ± 0.24 μmol e– (g char)–1]. The EAC of the MGAC
resulted in higher current responses because the contents of Fe (III) and oxygen functional groups in the MGAC were higher than those in the GAC. The EAC increased because Fe (III) can accept an electron to become Fe (II). Due to polarity and hydrophilicity, the oxygen functional groups can shorten the electron transfer distance, thereby enhancing the capacitance of the carbon materials [45].

sections.heading: 3.5. Microbial community
sections.text:
The bacterial structures showed higher relative abundance of Thermogutta, Levilinea, and Acetobacteroides (Fig. 8A), which are H2producing bacteria [2,46,47]. Thermogutta accounted for 15.5% of the control, 9.2% of the GAC, and 20.8% of the MGAC. Levilinea accounted for 8.4% of the control, 15.5% of the GAC, and 12.8% of the MGAC. Acetobacteroides accounted for 10.2% of the control, 6.9% of the GAC, and 4.0% of the MGAC. The rank reads of Thermogutta accounted for 6106 of the control, 5576 of the GAC, and 15574 of the MGAC. The rank reads of Levilinea accounted for 3310 of the control, 9409 of the GAC, and 9582 of the MGAC. The rank reads of Acetobacteroides accounted for 4020 of the control, 4199 of the GAC, and 3005 of the MGAC. The relative abundances and rank reads of these H2-producing bacteria were dominant, but H2 was not detected in the biogas because it was utilized in situ by the methanogens [47]. The relative abundances and rank reads of the H2-producing bacteria were increased, thereby enhancing the growth of the methanogens and the H2-utilizing archaea.
The relative abundance of exoelectrogens was increased by the addition of the MGAC, which accounted for 2.2% of the control, 2.8% of the GAC and 3.4% of the MGAC. The rank reads of the exoelectrogens were increased by the addition of the conductive particles, which accounted for 1110 of the control, 1372 of the GAC, and 2550 of the
MGAC. Pseudomonas, which is Fe (III) oxide-reducing bacteria, accounted for 1.5% of the control, 1.70% of the GAC, and 2.3% of the MGAC. The rank reads of the Pseudomonas were increased by the addition of the conductive particles, which accounted for 577 of the control, 1032 of the GAC, and 1728 of the MGAC. There are several possible ways in which MGAC can enhance the electron transfer
between the exoelectrogens and methanogens. As a conductive bridge, the MGAC can transfer electrons and thus enhance the DIET. As extracellular mediators, Fe3+/Fe2+ and riboflavin can also transfer electrons and thus enhance the IET [19]. After running the anaerobic systems for 30 days, the Fe content in the MGAC decreased (Fig. S9). This observation suggests that Fe3+/Fe2+ was involved in the IET and was discharged with the effluent [48]. The electron transfer between the exoelectrogens and methanogens was enhanced by the addition of the MGAC, which in turn enhanced methane production [12,49].
The methanogens were the dominant archaea in the anaerobic system (Fig. 8B). The microbial structures showed that Methanothrix, Methanolinea, Methanomassiliicoccus the most predominant genera. The GAC exhibited the highest abundance of Methanothrix (58.5%), which was 19% higher than that of the control (49.2%) and 52% higher than that of the MGAC (38.5%). Methanothrix (acetoclastic methanogens) can use acetate as the sole energy source for methanogenesis and growth [7]. The relative abundance of Methanothrix was increased by the addition of the GAC, and the acetoclastic methanogenesis was enhanced, which in turn enhanced methane production. Methanothrix can accept extracellular electrons in the methanogenic archaea [7]. The concentration of riboflavin was increased by the addition of the GAC, which indicates that the GAC enhanced the IET between the bacteria and Methanothrix.
The abundances of Methanolinea (19.8%) and Methanomassiliicoccus (16.1%) were increased by the addition of the MGAC. The MGAC exhibited the highest total abundance of Methanolinea and Methanomassiliicoccus, which was 44% higher than that of the control (13.8% of Methanolinea and 11.2% of Methanomassiliicoccus), and 62% higher than that of GAC (14.3% of Methanolinea and 7.9% of Methanomassiliicoccus). Methanolinea and Methanomassiliicoccus can use hydrogen to produce methane [50,51], which indicates that the MGAC enhanced the conversion of hydrogen to methane. The MGAC enhanced the relative abundance of the H2-utilizing archaea, which in turn enhanced methane production.
The key functional gene copies were increased by the addition of the particles (Fig. S10). Acetyl-CoA synthetase (ACS) plays a key role in acetoclastic methanogenesis [29]. The GAC exhibited the highest number of genes copies of ACS (4.4× 106), which was 57% higher than that of the control (2.8× 106) and 52% higher than that of the MGAC (2.9× 106). The GAC enhanced acetoclastic methanogenesis by increasing the abundance of Methanothrix. Coenzyme F420 acted as an electron carrier in the methanogenic pathway by utilizing CO2 and H2 [52,53]. The transfer mechanism depends on catalyzation by coenzyme F420-reducing hydrogenase [54]. The MGAC exhibited the highest number of genes copies of coenzyme F420-reducing hydrogenase (6.4× 106), which was 28% higher than that of the control (5.0× 106) and 14% higher than that of the GAC (5.6× 106). This result indicates that the MGAC enhanced the methanogenesis from CO2 and H2 by increasing the abundance of Methanolinea. Thus, the particles enhanced the electron transfer of the corresponding methanogenic pathway by increasing the number of key functional proteins.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
To enhance methanogenesis, MGAC loaded with nano-Fe3O4 was prepared using a co-precipitation method. This new material provided multiple improvements to the treatment of low-strength wastewater, such as increasing conductivity, improving methane production, and reducing effluent tCOD concentration. The effluent tCOD of the MGAC was 43% lower than that of the control and 33% lower than that of the GAC. The methane production of the MGAC was 3.6 times that of the control and 57% higher than that of the GAC over one cycle. The MGAC exhibited stronger electrochemical response of riboflavin, which indicates that the MGAC enhanced the IET by riboflavin. The abundances of the H2-producing bacteria and H2-utilizing archaea were increased by the addition of the MGAC, which increased the methane proportion
in the biogas. The abundance of exoelectrogens was increased by the addition of the MGAC, which indicates that the MGAC enhanced the electron transfer between the exoelectrogens and the methanogens.

sections.text: This work was supported by the National Key R&D Program of China (Grant No. 2016YFE0106500), National Natural Science Fund of China (Grant No. 51408156), and National Key R&D Program of China (Grant No. 2016YFC0401101). Authors also acknowledged the Open Project of State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology (No. QA201935).

sections.text: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2019.05.216.

referenceMentions.context: However, low-strength wastewater does not meet the organic concentration requirements for anaerobic digestion because of its low degradation rate and low electron transfer efficiency [1].
Recently, direct interspecies electron transfer (DIET) between Geobacter and Methanothrix species has been confirmed to occur during methane production [2].

Moreover, naturally occurring or artificially supplemented conductive materials can facilitate the DIET process by acting as a bridge connecting the cell surfaces of electron-donating and electron-accepting microbes [3].
PANI acts as an electron aisle that accelerates electron transfer and improves methane production [5].
GAC is used in anaerobic digestion because it is inexpensive, in addition to having no biological toxicity, high surface area, and numerous pores that are available for modifications [7].
As a carrier of microorganisms, GAC is used in the anaerobic digestion of low-strength wastewater for enhancing electron transfer between exoelectrogens and methanogens [8,9].
As a carrier of microorganisms, GAC is used in the anaerobic digestion of low-strength wastewater for enhancing electron transfer between exoelectrogens and methanogens [8,9].
Magnetite is a common ironbearing material that can improve interspecies electron transfer and enhance methane generation [3].
Ferrosoferric oxide (Fe3O4), which is the main component of magnetite, has been confirmed to improve methane production by enhancing electron transfer [10].

Extracellular solid conductive materials can transfer electrons between bacteria as pili or c-type cytochromes, and they can be used as electron donors or acceptors for the growth of these microorganisms [11].

Nano-Fe3O4 has received increasing consideration as a catalyst in anaerobic digestion due to its ease of handling, recovery with an external magnetic field, and high catalytic activity in various organic transformations [17].

However, nanoFe3O4 particles often tend to aggregate due to nanometer-scale and magnetic effects during catalytic transformations, which remarkably decreases catalytic activity owing to the decrease in active surface area [12].
003) was obtained from a laboratory anaerobic reactor that was operated replacing this selection with simulated domestic wastewater (400mg L COD) over two months [21].

To investigate the electrochemical activity and extracellular electron transfer of the MGAC, cyclic voltammetry (CV) and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) were performed using the three electrodes [25].

The functional differences between the different samples were analyzed by functional genes speculated from the results of the 16S sequencing [29].
The FTIR spectrum of the MGAC exhibited broadband at 560 cm, which corresponds to Fe-O stretching vibration [31].

The higher conductivity of MGAC improved the electron transfer between the bacteria and the archaea, which can increase the digestion rate of the substrate [18].
The MGAC had a higher specific surface area, which indicates a higher adsorption capacity for substrate and a higher degradation rate [34].

The MGAC increased tCOD removal efficiency and methane production because the nano-Fe3O4 had a bio-stimulating effect on the methanogens, which in turn facilitated the conversion of the substrate to methane [35].
and thus bridged the cell connection and accelerated the electron transfer [18].
DPV tests with higher sensitivity were performed to detect the electrochemically active substance and further elucidate the electron transfer pathway [40].

As a conductive conduit, this addition accelerated the process by which the cytochrome C transmitted electrons to the extracellular electron receptors and thus enhanced the DIET [43].

Due to polarity and hydrophilicity, the oxygen functional groups can shorten the electron transfer distance, thereby enhancing the capacitance of the carbon materials [45].

The relative abundances and rank reads of these H2-producing bacteria were dominant, but H2 was not detected in the biogas because it was utilized in situ by the methanogens [47].
As extracellular mediators, Fe/Fe and riboflavin can also transfer electrons and thus enhance the IET [19].
This observation suggests that Fe/Fe was involved in the IET and was discharged with the effluent [48].
The electron transfer between the exoelectrogens and methanogens was enhanced by the addition of the MGAC, which in turn enhanced methane production [12,49].
The electron transfer between the exoelectrogens and methanogens was enhanced by the addition of the MGAC, which in turn enhanced methane production [12,49].
Methanothrix (acetoclastic methanogens) can use acetate as the sole energy source for methanogenesis and growth [7].
Methanothrix can accept extracellular electrons in the methanogenic archaea [7].
Methanolinea and Methanomassiliicoccus can use hydrogen to produce methane [50,51], which indicates that the MGAC enhanced the conversion of hydrogen to methane.
